5.1.19  12:33 am   one of my biggest problems when combining melody with chords is that ending a melodic phrase by going M3 -> 1 is one of the strongest sounding melodic resolutions, but the strongest harmonic resolutions I know (V7->I, bII7->I, iv6->I) all do not work well with the M3rd of the tonic chord included (at least when the blending is clear enough to hear the dissonance). I know V13 is a thing, but I always think that sounds weird unless the 7th is lower than the 13th, which usually makes the chord sound muddy.

The best way I've found is iii with the 5th of the tonic scale in the bass, but that never is quite as satisfying as I want it to be.

      Do you have a go-to for this situation? I know in And The Day Goes On, you just did a I chord with the 5th in the bass going to a normal I chord with lots of voices moving down and it totally worked there

      but like iii/5th

      it leaves me with a bit of harmonic blue balls when I try to apply it in general.

4.30.19  10:27 am   I have a theory that everyone is everyone else. Like, you have person A and B, and A thinks it's A and not B, and B thinks it's B and not A. But A and B are in the brain of person C (or you can think of it like C is reading the minds of both A and B). So C has the experience of thinking it's A and not B, and thinking it's B and not A, and maybe independent C thoughts not in A or B.
Maybe people are like A and B, but we're all just C. Helps to explain why I feel like me and not like someone else. Any constructive criticism on this theory?
